entry.title: Pelican usage notes
entry.summary:
Setup notes

Initialize files:

> mv .project .project-no
> pelican-quickstart
> mv .project-no .project

Move eclipse project file away, pelican-quickstart confuses with it and back after pelican-quickstart.

Run notes

First terminal:

> cd ~/wrk/blog
> make serve

and open browser to http://localhost:8000

Second terminal:

> cd ~/wrk/blog
> pelican -r

This run until there rst syntax error, then restart pelican -r on rst errors.

make devserver does not practically work, because pelican process terminates on rst text errors. pelican .r does not work either. develop_server.sh also messes up with pid-file.

Beam up to github pages

Install ghp-import:

> pip3 install ghp-import

entry.title: Creating user github pages
entry.summary:
According the instructions in https://help.github.com/categories/20/articles

Creating user github pages. Project pages has a bit more complex procedure.

Not using jekyll.

  1. Create repository in github
  1. Clone the repository to local computer
  1. Create test index.html file, commit and push to github
  1. Check results

entry.title: Pulling with Egit
entry.summary:
Pulling from remote repository with Egit does not always work right.

<project> -> Team -> Pull might give this:

which is incorrect information.

Workaround is to revert command line git (as usual):

entry.title: Creating static blog generator
entry.summary:
Docutils

  1. Create a parser:

    parser = docutils.parsers.rst.Parser()

    Several optional arguments may be passed to modify the parser's behavior. Please see Customizing the Parser below for details.

  2. Gather input (a multi-line string), by reading a file or the standard input:

    input = sys.stdin.read()

  3. Create a new empty docutils.nodes.document tree:

    document = docutils.utils.new_document(source, settings)

    See docutils.utils.new_document() for parameter details.

  4. Run the parser, populating the document tree:

    parser.parse(input, document)

http://kaizer.se/wiki/rst_customize.py

http://docutils.sourceforge.net/docs/dev/hacking.html

Related

pelican https://github.com/getpelican/pelican/

http://www.voidspace.org.uk/python/firedrop2/

http://pyblosxom.github.com/

mynt https://github.com/Anomareh/mynt

wok

frozen flask

hyde https://github.com/lakshmivyas/hyde

tinkerer

nikola https://github.com/ralsina/nikola

chisel https://github.com/dz/chisel

growl https://github.com/xfire/growl/tree

@memcache_decorator('rst_parser')
def _parse(initial_header_level, transform_doctitle, story):
    parts = publish_parts(
        story,
        writer_name='html',
        settings_overrides={
            'initial_header_level': initial_header_level,
            'doctitle_xform': transform_doctitle
            })
    return parts['body']

entry.title: Making remote git repository
entry.summary:
To the remote server:

local> ssh remote.net
> cd /home/user/git
> mkdir project.git
> cd project.git
> git --bare init
> git config core.sharedrepository 1
> git config receive.denyNonFastforwards true

On local workstation:

> cd project
> git remote add origin ssh://user@remote.net/home/user/git/project.git
> git push -u origin master

Links:

  • http://qugstart.com/blog/ruby-and-rails/create-a-new-git-remote-repository-from-some-local-files-or-local-git-repository/
